Message.Title: Intel up pre market while ARMH is down.
Message.Msg: Google Finance shows Intel currently up 20 cents in pre market trade while ARMh is down 84 cents.

Message.Title: Milky Way-2 Wins #1 Supercomputer in the World
Message.Msg: Funny that they are using the term "neo-heterogeneous" or "new" method for heterogeneous computing. Not that "old" method. They used Sandy Bridge and PHI to take the top. "System uses a neo-heterogeneous architecture including 32000 of upcoming Intel Xeon processor E5-2600 V2 processors and 48000 Intel Xeon Phi coprocessors built into an innovative new architecture with a proprietary high speed interconnect known as TH Express-2."

Topic.Title: Milky Way-2 Wins #1 Supercomputer in the World

Message.Msg: "Sandy Bridge"?????? EXCUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUSE ME! They threw me by their numbering. The Xeon used in getting these numbers is an UNANNOUNCED version of an Ivy Bridge with 12 (TWELVE) cores. From the Aregister. The chip that Intel didn't want you to know about On the x86 portion of the Tianhe-2 system, NUDT has opted for a top-bin Ivy Bridge-EP part, and Dongarra says it is, in fact, a twelve-core Xeon E5 v2 chip (specifically, the E5-2692) running at 2.2GHz. Intel is sure to be annoyed by the release of this information, since it has not announced the core count of these processors. There has been some yammering about a ten-core part up until now, but now we know there is a twelve-core part. Intel is not expected to announce these Xeon E5 v2 processors until the fall, most likely at Intel Developer Forum in September. But as was the case with the eight-core "Sandy Bridge-EP" Xeon E5 v1 chips, Intel has ramped up production ahead of the formal launch and cherry-picked some big HPC customers to show off the processor.

Message.Title: MARKET TALK: Numis Cuts ARM Holdings To Reduce
Message.Msg: MARKET TALK: Numis Cuts ARM Holdings To Reduce Last update: 6/17/2013 6:26:21 AM 1026 GMT [Dow Jones] Numis downgrades ARM Holdings (ARM.LN) to reduce from hold and cuts target price to 700p from 920p as it sees the company losing market share to Intel Corporation (INTC). Cuts forecasts of ARM's CPU share in the smartphone market to 72% from 86% in 2014 and beyond. Says the balance of 28% goes to Intel, however there are scenarios where Intel could gain up to 40% share if it enabled some breakthrough devices at the likes of Sony, Amazon and Motorola. Numis reduces its forecasts of ARM's share in the tablet market to 70% from 80%. Cuts EPS forecasts for FY 2014, 2015 and 2016 to 21.5p, 24.4p and 29.9p respectively. ARM is the top faller on the FTSE 100, down 3.3% at 834p. Contact us in London. +44-20-7842-9464

Topic.Title: MARKET TALK: Numis Cuts ARM Holdings To Reduce

Message.Msg: Wow, now those are some truly massive cuts to ARM's estimated market shares! Well, it's not like we didn't see them coming. ARM is blowing through $40 in pre-market and is tapping on $39 (39.08 at the moment). Wall Street remains in denial though as Intel at this point is up a mere 22 cents. If ARM is down by 3.5 percent then Intel should be up by 3.5 percent. This total disconnect should start to resolve itself out soon. The big Wall Street firms have totally misplayed Intel and the chickens are now coming home to roost as fried chicken. With the Samsung event on Thursday, it's looking like a week of more palpable pain and disappointment and misery for Intel shorts. We will see if the manipulators have much success in propping ARM back up after the markets open... 2013: Year of the Intel Tablet 2014: Year of the Intel Smartphone

Topic.Title: MARKET TALK: Numis Cuts ARM Holdings To Reduce

Message.Msg: " If ARM is down by 3.5 percent then Intel should be up by 3.5 percent." If you rethink that you will see where it is wrong.

Message.Title: Microsoft Build Developers Conference 2013
Message.Msg: Rumour, speculation and what we would really like Microsoft to say at its developer conference //build/ from 26-28 June, 2013 in San Francisco. Google has its IO conference. Apple just had its WWDC (also in San Francisco) and the two hour keynote was interesting but not startling. Apple’s $1,600 tickets sold out in 71 seconds – Microsoft’s $2,000 tickets took not much longer. So it is my turn to predict what I would like Microsoft to do at its event. First Microsoft has several platforms so two hours may not cut it: Windows Pro 8 Windows Phone 8 Windows RT Windows Server Hardware e.g. Surface Entertainment e.g. Xbox Productivity – Office Programing Language – Visual Studio and Internet Explorer and HTML5 From itwire

Topic.Title: Microsoft Build Developers Conference 2013

Message.Msg: Overview Microsoft has been on the back foot while it converged its disparate ecosystem to Windows 8. Now it is time to aim for the sky and this event will be ‘encouraging’ and looking towards a unified Microsoft based future. It will also leverage off Intel’s successful Haswell launch citing that the combination of Windows 8.1, Intel Haswell and Atom Clover Trail+ and Bay Trail will turn the tide for Windows 8 take up. Windows 8 becomes 8.1 – the nomenclature is important as it signifies an incremental upgrade but we think it will be much more. First it may introduce subscription based pricing which is favoured by small business and enterprise, perhaps less so for home users. But this has to happen to stop fragmentation and support progress. Next it brings back the Start button and gives Steve Ballmer a ‘mea culpa’ moment to prove he is human. Resizable apps will also be a good move. From itwire

Topic.Title: Microsoft Build Developers Conference 2013

Message.Msg: Hardware Surface products are Microsoft’s attempt to set standards with vanilla flavoured Windows devices that its OEM partners can meet or beat. It also uses these to test markets where OEM’s may be unwilling to tread. I predict that Surface RT won’t even be mentioned... From itwire

Okay I'm sticking with Intel should be up by at least 4 percent today to start to reel some of that in. Show me your calc's...

Message.Title: Why is it we do not except change and move forward?
Message.Msg: Baseball is thinking of putting baseball helmets on pitchers. Just do it. OR--if you want to avoid that, simply move the mound back 5 feet. Either will do the job. What? You say baseball is pure and how could we ever think of moving this mound back. But wait a minute. After the pitchers started to dominate completely in the late 1960s and early 1970s, baseball lowered the mound so do not tell me you cannot move the mound. It was done with radical increases in run scored resulting. But better yet--wear a helmet and move the mound back 5 feet. OK---then we have Intel and the shift to its chips in phones and tablets which will shock the world. Deal with it. It is inevitable just like is the death of the Tea party in National elections. When 1 in 4 people are non-white as now, a party, the GOP based upon wanting to go back in time when whites ruled and we had segregation is not going to happen is it. OK--you think things are bad now repuuups? Well wait until 1 in 3 voters are non-white in 8 years. The Dems will be able to run a broomstick as a candidate and win the White House by then. How about when it is 50-50? Well then the Dem primary race will be treated as the Presidential race because the Repub will lose after that getting 30% of the vote or less. Intel will hit 40 this year and 100 before the end of the decade and maybe and maybe even before the end of 2016. Things are changing boys. Deal with it.

Message.Title: Intel Showcases Atom based Mobile Devices and Microarchitecture Silvermont
Message.Msg: The frequency of BayTrail Linux kernel source code submissions and patches has picked up substantially during the last two weeks. This happened in late May for Haswell which would point to a mid-July introduction if the timelines are similar "June 17, 2013: Intel India organized a mobility roadshow last week, in Bengaluru to outline its plan to accelerate new mobile device experiences across the company’s growing portfolio of smartphone and tablet offerings. At the roadshow, the company also showcased its brand new, low-power, high-performance microarchitecture named Silvermont and shared details about the forthcoming Intel® Atom™ SoC for tablets (“Bay Trail-T”) due in the market this year. “The mobile devices ecosystem in India is evolving rapidly and is seeing a lot of innovation. Localized products that bring alive compelling user experiences will drive greater differentiation, and we are committed to accelerate and invest in our efforts to bring the best of next-gen mobility with a focus on smartphones, tablets and wireless communications,” said George Chacko, Product Marketing Manager, Intel APAC. "

Message.Msg: It is amazing how fast Concurrent (CCUR) is growing, they reported that their GAAP EPS last quarter was up 175% year-over-year and they just raised their dividend by 100% to $0.48 for a yield here at $8 of 6%! CCUR has trailing free cash flow of $5.6 million or $0.64 per share. CCUR's rival Seachange (SEAC) is now trading for $11.54 or 28.15X its free cash flow of $0.41 per share. If CCUR was worth 28.15X free cash flow the stock would be $18! CCUR leads the video on demand (VOD) industry with 2.4 million streams deployed worldwide, ahead of SEAC and CSCO! Last week at the Cable Show in Washington DC, Comcast announced they will be launching their own cloud based Network DVR technology later this year. CCUR recently won a patent for Network DVR technology and has already deployed a form of Network DVR technology for Time Warner Cable (TWC) and Bright House, with CCUR deploying their Start Over and Look Back services! CCUR has a total VOD reach of 50 million households for a 30% market share!

Message.Title: Intel leak reveals plans for 8-core Haswell E-Series CPU
Message.Msg: from techradar Despite the spotlight still very much remaining on Intel's battery boosting "Haswell" CPU, a fresh leak suggests that the chipmaker may be putting raw power back on the menu before long. Intel could be set to launch its first 8-core CPU for desktops in the second half of next year, beginning with its 2014 Haswell-E enthusiast-grade chip, according to a report on VR-Zone. Haswell-E processors will apparently be built on the 22nm 2nd generation Hi-k process and will pack up to 20MB of L3 cache. The chip also looks set to feature Intel Turbo Boost 2, in addition to support for DDR4 and 16 threads thanks to hyper-threading technology, all supported by Intel's forthcoming Wellsburg motherboard chipset. The company is apparently looking to do away with the 4-core base model in favour of 6-core and 8-core versions of the CPU. Raw power In terms of raw power, it's the biggest leap since Intel announced its first 6-core processor for desktops back in 2010. The superfast chip could primarily deliver the goods for three types of users: powerhungry gamers, overclockers, and content creators in the video, photo and music fields.

Message.Title: Intel Powers the World’s Fastest Supercomputer, Reveals New and Future High Performance Computing Technologies
Message.Msg: from businesswire “Knights Landing” – A Choice of Coprocessor or CPU Intel revealed details of its second generation Intel Xeon Phi products aimed to further increase their supercomputing capabilities. Codenamed “Knights Landing,” the next generation of Intel MIC Architecture-based products will be available as a coprocessor or a host processor (CPU) and manufactured using Intel’s 14nm process technology featuring second generation 3-D tri-gate transistors. As a PCIe card-based coprocessor, “Knights Landing” will handle offload workloads from the system’s Intel Xeon processors and provide an upgrade path for users of current generation of coprocessors, much like it does today. However, as a host processor directly installed in the motherboard socket, it will function as a CPU and enable the next leap in compute density and performance per watt, handling all the duties of the primary processor and the specialized coprocessor at the same time. When used as a CPU, “Knights Landing” will also remove programming complexities of data transfer over PCIe, common in accelerators today. To further boost the performance for HPC workloads, Intel will significantly increase the memory bandwidth for all “Knights Landing” products by introducing integrated on-package memory. This will allow customers to take full advantage of available compute capacity without encountering memory bandwidth bottlenecks experienced today [Looks like Intel has 14nm right around the corner.]

Message.Title: Intel’s Top-Secret Lab Is Working On Google Glass-Like Gadgets
Message.Msg: from business insider In 2012, Intel spent $10.1 billion on research and development, making it one of the biggest R&D spenders in the world. Half of that money goes to wildly experimental tech, Justin Rattner, Intel CTO said Monday on stage at the Bloomberg Next Big Thing Summit. “50 cents of every dollar goes into exploratory stuff and the other 50 cents of every dollar goes into tech that serves the business unit that makes the money,” he said. Much of that experimental tech is on Intel-designed devices, though Rattner stopped short of announcing plans to bring any of these devices to market. He deftly sidestepped a question on if he thought Google Glass would become a mainstream device. Glass is built using ARM chips, Intel’s competitor, so it would have been newsworthy if he endorsed it. Even so, Intel’s lab is working on wearable tech, he said, and he does see a big future for alternatives to Glass. “Wearable computers will come in a variety of forms. Things that look like watches, head-worn devices like Google Glass of all sorts, and bio-sensors sewn into clothing,” he said. The labs are focused on the underlying technology needed for wearable devices, rather than prototypes of the devices themselves. They’re working on chips and sensors, something he called a “sensor hub.” The goal is to extend battery life. The idea is that the sensors are working all the time, but the phone doesn’t stay powered up while they run. “If something significant happens, it can decide to power up the phone,” he describes. As for a more direct alternative to Glass, he only smiled and said, “We’re looking at novel display devices.” Ultimately, he wants to see Intel solve its reputation as a laggard in the mobile market. “We must see Intel move faster,” he said, explaining that “we’ve been legitimately accused of trying to get everything perfect before it comes to market … today people are literally bringing systems to market with much less of that mentality,” he says and Intel

Message.Title: BK Broiler wants Intel to move faster
Message.Msg: Intel’s Technology Chief Says CEO Wants New Products Faster By Ian King & Emily Chang - Jun 17, 2013 2:48 PM CT. Intel Corp. (INTC), the world’s largest chipmaker, is being pushed by Chief Executive Officer Brian Krzanich to bring new products to market more quickly and then update to refine them. “He wants to see Intel move faster. That’s very clear,” Justin Rattner, the company’s chief technology officer, said today. “We’ve been legitimately accused of trying to get everything perfect before it comes to market.” Rattner, who spoke at the Bloomberg Next Big Thing Summit in Half Moon Bay, California, said that the company is going to respond to a mobile market where products are introduced then rapidly updated. Intel has struggled to translate its dominance of personal computer processors into a foothold in tablets and smartphones. The company is working hard to develop chip technology that draws less power and enables laptops and other computing devices to get the kind of all-day battery life offered by phones, Rattner said. “There’s no question the age of handheld mobile devices and soon wearable devices are upon us,” he said. “That requires a complete rethink of how you design those systems and how you program those systems and how you provision those devices.” Intel CEO Krzanich was promoted to the top job at the Santa Clara, California-based chipmaker in May, succeeding Paul Otellini, who retired. Krzanich, a former factory manager, said the company will speed up efforts to kick start its work on chips for mobile devices that threaten the PC industry. Global tablet shipments are expected to eclipse PCs by 2015 as consumers flock to smaller, more affordable machines, according to researcher IDC. Intel ended 2012 with less than one percent market share in tablets and phones, according to Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. research.

Topic.Title: Milky Way-2 Wins #1 Supercomputer in the World

Message.Msg: Intel PHI replaced the NVIDIA Tesla cards that were used in the first machine. "Just like it was two and a half years ago, the new number one will probably be a Chinese computer. It was supposed to be a surprise and is still under NDA at Intel, but Linpack creator and Top500 co-organiser Jack Dongarra could not hold back the delight about his visit to the National University of Defense Technology (NUDT) and has already spilled the beans in a report about the new Tianhe 2. Unlike the Tianhe (Milky Way) 1A, which relies on NVIDIA Tesla cards, the Tianhe 2 draws on 48,000 Xeon Phi cards, reaching a theoretical peak performance of 55 petaflops. In real terms, with Linpack, it achieves 33.8 petaflops, in which the 384,000 CPU cores with the officially still unreleased 12-core Ivy Bridge EP (Xeon E5-2692v2 with 2.2GHz) play a role too."

Topic.Title: Huge XP Replacement Wave on the Way

Message.Msg: I know that this story bodes well for Intel upgrade cycles, at least from the initial impression. It was introduced in September of 2001. So, it's going on a dozen year old. The thing that makes it sad to lose in perspective of Intel is that at the time a fairly robust system would have around 512 megabytes of RAM and a 40GB hard drive was considered a fairly large drive. A highly stripped down version can install in under one gig of space and a sloppy install is around 8GB. With the new smartphones hitting the market powered by Intel one of the neat things to try would be making a dual boot and running XP. Perhaps if Microsoft went to a very low annual subscription on XP they would find funding to develop it further. I could see how hooking it up to external USB, and monitor and running an actual XP session from a phone would have it's benefits, especially in enterprise situations where systems are locked down hard. Not for everyday use but in emergencies this would be amazing.
